1:
I was born to a very close-knit Maharashtrian family in Mumbai’s Bandra East and lived in the
Sahitya Sahawas colony, a residential co-operative for writers.

Nitin, initially a chemistry teacher, subsequently worked for Air India and I
remember on one occasion, when I was ten, his flight was delayed and he had to wait at the Centaur
(now Sahara Star) hotel in Mumbai.

In the early 1980s Chinese cuisine was
becoming popular in Mumbai and, having heard so much about it, my colony friends made a plan to
go out for a meal together.

From a financial point of view, it wasn’t easy to bring up four
children in Mumbai, but our parents never let us feel any pressure.

In the wars again
I had a lot of adventures as a child, but one that stands out is when I was cut under my eye while
playing at Shivaji Park, the breeding ground of cricketers in Mumbai, and had to return home covered
in blood.

I asked a friend of mine to give me a lift on his bicycle, and anyone who
knows Mumbai will realize what a difficult task that is, especially with heavy cricket kitbags in tow.

The match, which involved Mumbai’s Ranji Trophy Probables, started early in the morning and the
plan was for a pair of fast bowlers to bowl at the batsmen for five or six overs before they were rested
and a new pair were asked to bowl with a new ball.

It was only later, when I was selected in the
Mumbai team and came to know Raju well, that I finally told him the real reason for not wearing a
helmet.

Ramakant Achrekar’s coaching camp, where a lot of Mumbai’s top cricketers had learnt their game,
was Ajit’s answer.
2:
He played for a number of Mumbai clubs, including the Gul
Mohar Mills and Mumbai Port, and played a first-class match for the State Bank of India against
Hyderabad in 1963.

When I was growing up he was undoubtedly one of the most accomplished
coaches in Mumbai.

From his own schooldays at Balmohan Vidyamandir, my brother Ajit knew that compared to other
schools in Mumbai, Shardashram was by far the best organized in its approach to cricket, and that’s
why he took me along to Achrekar Sir’s nets in Shivaji Park to try my luck at being a part of his
summer camp.

My induction into the
Mumbai cricket circuit could have ended in failure – but for Ajit’s insistence.

The rule in Mumbai at the time was that a
player’s name only appeared in print if he had scored 30 runs.

The next morning, when my name duly
appeared in a Mumbai paper, Achrekar Sir was seriously unhappy with what I had done and told me
off for consenting to have runs added to my personal tally when I hadn’t scored them.
The first-match jinx continued in my first season for the Mumbai Under-15 team in Pune in 1985.

During the break Sir would often give me some money to go
and have a vada pav (a popular Mumbai fast food) or a soft drink as a treat.

Anyone who has been on a Mumbai bus at peak hours will
know just how difficult it is to get a seat.

For those unfamiliar with the intricacies of Mumbai cricket, the Giles Shield is
meant for boys under the age of fourteen and Harris Shield for those under sixteen.

These tournaments
are acknowledged as breeding grounds for young talent in Mumbai and good performances tend to get
noticed in the city’s cricket circles.

In the semi-final of the Harris Shield against St Xavier’s in February 1988, a three-day game, we were
84–2 when I went in to bat at number four, with Vinod Kambli, an extremely talented youngster in
Mumbai’s cricket circles at the time, already at the crease, having gone in at number three.

It was my first competitive game at CCI and a number of Mumbai
cricket luminaries were present to see us bat in the final.

On certain days he would even drive me all the way across Mumbai on his scooter to get me to
matches on time.
Achrekar Sir has undoubtedly made a significant contribution to cricket in Mumbai and India.

Throughout my career, before each tour and each series for India, I would make four visits that were
very important to me: to two temples in Mumbai, the Ganesh temple in Shivaji Park and the
Siddhivinayak temple in Prabhadevi; to my aunt and uncle; and to Achrekar Sir.

Coaches from across India had been asked to name
talented youngsters and my name was suggested by Vasu Paranjpe, veteran Mumbai cricketer and one
of India’s best coaches.

The first break
All the hard work under the watchful supervision of Sir finally paid off when I was picked in the squad
to represent Mumbai in the Ranji Trophy on 14 November 1987.
Despite making the Mumbai squad, I did not make it to the final XI in any of the matches.

In 1987 I remember playing for the Mumbai Under-15

 team at Cuttack in Eastern India.

Ranji Trophy debut
The following year, I was watched closely by Mumbai captain Dilip Vengsarkar in the Cricket Club of
India nets when the Indian team came to play a match against the touring New Zealand team.

Vengsarkar was impressed with the way I played against Kapil Dev and sometime later, on 10
December 1988, when I was fifteen, he told the selectors that I was ready to play for Mumbai against
Gujarat, giving me my first big break.

I finished the 1988–89 season as Mumbai’s highest run-scorer
and made half-centuries in six of the seven matches I played.

Mumbai lost a hard-fought semi-final
against Delhi and I ended my debut season with a respectable batting average of 64.77.

My performances for Mumbai got me selected for the season-opening Irani Trophy match at the
beginning of November 1989.

I wasn’t prepared to lead a retired cricketer’s life just yet

Mumbai’s first Ranji match of the season, which was also my last, turned out to be fascinating.

Losing him during the 1999 World

domestic competition in India, was started in 1933–34 and named after the famous KS Ranjitsinhji,

4:
India in England, July–August 1990
After the New Zealand series, India travelled to England for what was our most important assignment
of the year.

India in England, July–August 1990
After the New Zealand series, India travelled to England for what was our most important assignment
of the year.

India had won a Test series in England in 1986 and we were all looking forward to
repeating the feat.

I had been to England twice before, in 1987–88 and 1988–89, as part of the Star Cricket Club, the
team of Kailash Gattani (a former fast bowler who played first-class cricket for Rajasthan in Indian
domestic cricket).

In the second match England produced a better performance, batting first, with Robin Smith, the
South African-born middle-order batsman, contributing 103 to their total of 281.

My only significant contribution in the match was a catch off leg-spinner Narendra Hirwani’s
bowling to dismiss England’s batting mainstay Allan Lamb in the second innings.

Second Test, Old Trafford, 9–14 August 1990
In the first innings at Old Trafford, England once again put together a total of more than 500, with
centuries from Gooch and Mike Atherton, and we simply had to get as close to their score as possible
in our reply.

It was evident that England
would want to score quickly and set us a target.

Allan Lamb made a hundred in the England second
innings and on the final day they declared on 320–4, leaving us ninety-two overs to bat out.

Time was gradually running out for England and
restlessness was creeping in.

There was still some time left in the day’s play and England could press for victory
if I got out.

Both umpires, John Hampshire and
John Holder, congratulated me on my hundred and all the England players walked up to me to offer
some kind words.

I asked our manager Madhav Mantri, a
former Test cricketer who toured England with India in the 1950s, if it was compulsory or if I could
just skip it.

The third Test match, at The Oval at the end of August, was another draw, which meant that we lost
the series 0–1, but I was still reasonably satisfied with my performances in England and felt I had
taken a few important strides.

We lost to England and Australia by the narrow margin of nine runs and one run respectively
and our second match against Sri Lanka at Mackay on 28 February was washed out because of rain.

I had just landed in Mumbai on our return from the 1990 tour of England and was waiting to pick up
my bags when I first saw an extremely attractive woman looking down from the viewing gallery in the
airport.

At the time she was in England
with her parents, and her father, Anand Mehta, a former national bridge champion and a serious
cricket fan, had called her to catch a glimpse of the innings on television.

For that first visit, I was keen to offer Anjali something to eat and was disappointed to see that
hardly any of the chocolates I had brought back from England remained.

The century in England had made me a household name and people had started to ask for
autographs.
6:
I did not bother
asking about the contract and other details and was determined to make the most of this opportunity to
play in the County Championship in England.

A Yorkshire lad
I left for England towards the end of April 1992, right after my nineteenth birthday, and stayed there
for three and a half months.

I was not really used to driving in England and often opted
for the fastest lane while driving to the ground.

I had actually driven a little in England in 1991 when I was there to play a few games of league
cricket.

I had
agreed to play in an India–Pakistan festival match in London but had also committed to playing for a
Rest of the World XI versus England at Newcastle the following day.

I had wrongly believed that it was easy to get from any
part of England to another in two or three hours.

Over the years, the lessons
learnt from my stint at Yorkshire continued to help me whenever I toured England as part of the
Indian team.

I had toured England in 1990, of
course, but back then I had been with the Indian team and everything was arranged for us.

Every Mumbai cricketer who had played league cricket in England had spoken to
me about Solly bhai’s hospitality and it was natural that I should get in touch with him.

It’s named after Ranjitsinhji’s nephew
Duleepsinhji, who played for England in the early 1930s, and features teams representing the
country’s five zones: West, North, South, East and Central, It was suggested that I should play in it
before we left for what would be a challenging tour of South Africa in October.

Every side faces difficulties away from home and
at the end of the tough South Africa series we were looking forward to dishing out a few challenges to
Graham Gooch’s England when they toured India in February–March 1993.

England in India, January–March 1993
There’s nothing quite like playing in front of home crowds and in home conditions.

I remember hitting a short ball from
Paul Jarvis, the England fast bowler, over square leg to the boundary to win the game.

The English batsmen I had seen hitting through the line in England in
1990 were now struggling against the turning ball.

Playing spin in the subcontinent is quite a challenge and England were
finding it very difficult.

Despite some resistance
from Neil Fairbrother in their first innings, England were forced to follow on.

England must have been reasonably pleased to post their
biggest total of the series in their first innings, 347, with Graeme Hick making his highest Test score
of 178.
The England series marked the beginning of a very successful phase in Indian cricket.

India in England, the Test series, July–September 2002

India in England, the Test series, July–September 2002
I have always enjoyed playing in England, but on the 2002 tour it took the team a little time to adjust
to the conditions.

The first of the four Tests, at Lord’s, started on 25 July 2002 and England won pretty
convincingly, with Hussain making his highest score for five years and Michael Vaughan also
contributing a century.

Once again England posted a huge score, with Vaughan
again in good form, and we were faced with batting out the last day to survive.

By the time
England’s turn came, their task would be even more difficult, because the wicket was becoming
uneven and the odd ball had started to keep low.

There were no big partnerships and we
kept taking wickets at regular intervals, finally bowling England out for 273 and then enforcing the
follow-on.

Anil
did the rest, picking up four wickets, and we bowled England out for 309, winning the match by an
innings and 46 runs.

England, Sri Lanka and India were
the three teams playing for honours and we met England in the final after playing each other three
times in a round-robin format.

England, Sri Lanka and India were
the three teams playing for honours and we met England in the final after playing each other three

We had successfully chased down several high scores and we weren’t overawed by the
England total at Lord’s.

We’d heard

 that the England team had ordered champagne by the middle of our innings and had put a number of

I don’t know if this
story is true, but a number of our players suggested to the England team at the end of the game that it

England versus
India is always a big game, but this time it was the World Cup and it was a must-win game for both

 teams.

Durban always offers something for the fast
bowlers and I knew that Caddick and the other tall England bowlers would look to exploit the extra
bounce by bowling short of a length.

It was a dream start in a very big game and it took a great spell from Andrew Flintoff to bring
England back into the match.
The England innings started well for us with an incredible piece of fielding by Mohammad Kaif.
England were 6–1 and we had an early breakthrough.

He was getting
the ball to move both ways and was bowling at speeds between 140 and 145 kph, making it extremely
difficult for the England batsmen to negotiate his pace and swing.

By the thirtieth over England were
eight wickets down with more than 140 runs still required.

Beating
England and Pakistan were unforgettable high points, but the World Cup trophy was still eluding me.

23:
An epic encounter
Our next match was against England in Bangalore on 27 February and, as it was our first match at
home, the excitement was off the scale.
Something a little odd happened just hours before the England match.

Graeme Swann was England’s leading spinner and I hit him for consecutive sixes at the start of his
second spell, turning the momentum in our favour.

England were brilliant in reply and also benefited from the very heavy dew, which meant our
spinners had been rendered ineffective.

In conditions of heavy dew the ball just skids on to the bat,
something England were to encounter in their match against Ireland at Bangalore.

Against us, Andrew Strauss played one of his best ever one-day innings, making 158, and he almost
took England to victory before Zaheer pulled it back for us with a superb second spell, taking three
wickets for just 11.

India in England, July–August 2011
I rejoined the team in July 2011 and was looking forward to playing against a resurgent English side in
their home conditions.

The fact that our recently appointed coach, Duncan Fletcher, was
returning to take on the England team he used to coach with such success also added spice to the
series.

Back in 2005 I
encouraged him to play county cricket, and when he came back to India after playing his first season
in England, there was no doubt he was a more mature performer.

I don’t want to take anything
away from England, who played superb cricket throughout the series, but it was a remarkable
sequence of disasters and it wasn’t easy to cope with the loss of so many key players.

England had tall fast bowlers in Chris Tremlett and Stuart Broad and
I had serious trouble because the bowler’s hand was sometimes lost against the dark-coloured steps
above the sightscreen.

Although I wasn’t able to contribute much to the team, I forced myself to field towards the end of
the England innings, to make sure I would have an opportunity to bat on day five.

England ended up winning the first Test comfortably, thanks to centuries from Pietersen and Prior
and five wickets for James Anderson in the second innings.

In the second Test at Trent Bridge, starting
on 29 July, we came back strongly and Sreesanth and Ishant Sharma helped reduced England to 124–8
at one point in their first innings, but Swann and Broad managed to bail them out, taking their score to

 221.

In the third Test at Edgbaston, England won the match with their first-innings total of 710, which
included a career-best 294 from Alastair Cook and 104 from Eoin Morgan.

Stuck on ninety-nine
I had scored my ninety-eighth international hundred on 27 February 2011 while playing England in
our second World Cup game in Bangalore, but there was no mention of the 100th hundred in the media
at that stage.

I first became aware of all the fuss when I was on a family holiday in England in June 2011 before
the Test series.

At The Oval in the fourth and final Test, which started on 18 August, England scored 591 in their
first innings, with 235 from Ian Bell and another century from Pietersen.

Every run was
getting us closer to the England total.

It was important for the team to put the England slump behind us, especially as we had another
tough tour of Australia lined up for the end of the year.

England in India, November–December 2012
I thought I started well against England in the first Test at Ahmedabad on 15 November.

England in India, November–December 2012
I thought I started well against England in the first Test at Ahmedabad on 15 November.
Pragyan Ojha and Ravi Ashwin then got in on the act and ran through England in both innings.

The second Test started in Mumbai on 23 November and rather unexpectedly England turned things
around on the first day.

I felt that the pace and bounce of the Wankhede wicket would
help the England bowlers.

England had beaten us at the Wankhede in 2006 and I thought we should
have prepared a good batting wicket instead of a turner.

Monty had taken Sehwag’s wicket earlier in the innings and triggered a rare batting collapse on
home soil, which handed England control of the match.

England then batted excellently, with skipper Alastair Cook and Kevin Pietersen playing extremely
well in difficult batting conditions to set up the game.
England were brilliant in response and Cook again led from the front with a spectacular 190.

A skipper
leading from the front is always good for a team and England put us under pressure again with a 207run lead.

Till then the wicket had
appeared flat and even the England players were surprised.

Trott made a hundred in England’s second innings and the game ended in a
draw, meaning that we had lost the series 2–1.

England were easily the better team in the series but I must say I was terribly disappointed with the
way I performed in the six innings I played in those four Test matches.

Time for change
I took some time off after the England series to clear my mind after all the scrutiny and speculation
and to think carefully about my career.

I might not have made many runs in the England series, but
the way I was batting had given me enough confidence to carry on.

We witnessed how random it could be during our tour of
England in 2011–12, when DRS resulted in a number of wrong decisions.

At one swoop we had managed to erase
the unpleasant memories of losing to England at home and the team had started to come together
again.

Dilip Vengsarkar,

On the eve of the final I was given a superb gift by Hemant Kenkre, Sunil Gavaskar’s nephew,

Hemant had with him a set of pads used by Sunil Gavaskar,
the really light ones with blue padding inside, and decided to give them to me.
I felt very proud to wear pads once used by Sunil Gavaskar.

4:
It is about body
language and radiating confidence, something that the West Indian batting legend Viv Richards would
personify.

A guy wearing a cap got out and I immediately said, ‘I’ve seen him
somewhere before.’ As he got closer I said, ‘I don’t believe it – that’s Viv Richards!’
When he walked past us and headed up to his room, I turned to Sanjay and told him that I just had to
meet my hero.
17:

giving Shoaib a break after one disastrous over.

It was the best early assault
against Pakistan that I had been involved in and it could not have come at a more important time.

As with most India–Pakistan matches, however, there had to be a shift in momentum and against
the run of play Pakistan picked up two wickets in Waqar’s next over – first Sehwag and then Sourav
with the very next ball.
Pakistan were back in the match.
I just had to bat Pakistan out of the game.

They both made half-centuries and India had won a famous
contest, continuing our run of success against Pakistan in World Cups.

 playing Pakistan and as a result had had a lot of isotonic drinks.

India in Pakistan, March–April 2004
There was a lot of excitement about our tour to Pakistan.

India in Pakistan, March–April 2004
There was a lot of excitement about our tour to Pakistan.

Playing Pakistan is always a big occasion for
an Indian cricketer, and this was the first time we had played them in Pakistan since my debut series
in 1989.

Playing Pakistan is always a big occasion for
an Indian cricketer, and this was the first time we had played them in Pakistan since my debut series
in 1989.
As soon as we landed in Pakistan we realized just how different this tour would be.

I had not experienced security like that before and
it was a very strange feeling, because we were just sportsmen who had come to Pakistan to play
cricket.

After we had
scored 349 batting first, Pakistan responded well but came up short, with 344 in their fifty overs.

The final match was a thriller and we beat Pakistan by 40 runs in
the end.

I have fond memories of this match, having taken a very good catch to dismiss the Pakistan
captain Inzamam-ul-Haq.

I caught the ball above my head just inches from the
boundary rope and then sprinted towards my team-mates in the middle, knowing we had managed to
prise out the most important Pakistan wicket.

It was an incredible effort and coming
against Pakistan made it all the more special.

I
was informed that we were looking to give Pakistan an hour to bat and so would put them in with
fifteen overs left on the second day.

In fact, I was
pacing my innings so that I could reach my double hundred and we could still give Pakistan fifteen
overs to bat, as was the plan.

However, as it happened, I did not get to play a single ball in that over,
with Yuvraj on strike against Imran Farhat, Pakistan’s opening batsman and part-time leg-spinner.

Some of

 the Pakistan players were also in the gym but none of them spoke to me, sensing the state of mind I
was in.

It was when I was talking to Professor Shetty that Sanjay Manjrekar, who was in Pakistan as a
commentator, turned up in my room.
Before that I had had a part to play with the ball against Pakistan wicketkeeper Moin Khan.

Balaji picked
up four wickets and we restricted Pakistan to 224 in the first innings.

This time Pakistan had been outplayed and we finished the formalities on day four by bowling them
out for 245.
It was a terrific series win and our first in Pakistan in fifty years.

The Abdul Qadir over
After the Tests, we played a five-match one-day series in which none of the matches was played for
the scheduled fifty overs.

The Pakistanis
hadn’t expected me to hit it so far and Abdul Qadir, an experienced old hand at the time, walked up to
me and said, ‘Bachhe ko kyun mar rahe ho; dum hai to mujhe mar ke dikhao.’ (No point in hitting
sixes off a newcomer; if you have the skills, try and hit me.)

Straight after the match, Abdul Qadir walked up to me in true sportsmanlike

 manner and said ‘Bahut ala batting.’ (Very well batted.)

The first few days in New Zealand were not easy.

India in New Zealand, February–March 1990
The first few days in New Zealand were not easy.

Prabhakar needed an adapter to charge his gadgets and for
some reason decided to put on what he thought was a New Zealand accent while speaking to the
housekeeping staff in the hotel.

I could hear most of the New Zealand players calling me a
schoolboy, with plenty of F-words thrown in.

The next was pitched up and I had

offered to show us around Sydney, which I was in no mood to do.

He also refused to take any money from us after dropping us off at the hotel and
left his number in case we needed to go anywhere else in Sydney during our stay.

I ended
up batting against my dear friend Subroto Banerjee, the former India medium-fast bowler, who was
then a resident of Sydney, in the indoor nets for a good forty-five minutes.

Second Test, Sydney, 2–6 January 2008
We suffered a blow on the eve of the Sydney Test when Zaheer was forced to return to India with a
heel injury.

We did not agree with
what the referee had done and felt that the hearing at Sydney had been something of a farce.

The unpleasantness of Sydney would not go away and a number of issues remained to be
straightened out at the WACA, where India had never won a Test.

Reasons to be cheerful
After the game a number of bottles of champagne were opened in the dressing room and one was also
sent across to the touring Indian media contingent, who had played a very important role in standing
behind us during the Sydney controversy.

We all felt hurt by what had transpired in Sydney and the best way to vent our anger was on the cricket
field.
Sydney.

accept that Sri Lanka and not India would be travelling to Pakistan to play in the World Cup final
against Australia.

My return to international cricket finally happened on 25 October 2005 in the first ODI of a series

While I managed to play in the Sri Lanka series, followed by three Tests against Pakistan in January

May.

By the time the team returned from the West Indies and were ready to go to Sri Lanka for three
ODIs in August, I had recovered enough to join them, though throwing was still a bit of an issue.

game because of rain and the second and third games were abandoned completely – although it did at
least allow me more time to recover.

6:
Our next international assignment was a tour of South Africa towards the end
of the year and we had several months off in the interim.

It’s named after Ranjitsinhji’s nephew
Duleepsinhji, who played for England in the early 1930s, and features teams representing the
country’s five zones: West, North, South, East and Central, It was suggested that I should play in it
before we left for what would be a challenging tour of South Africa in October.

India in South Africa, November 1992–January 1993
It was a historic tour because it was the first time the South Africans had played a Test series at home
since returning to the international fold in 1991.

We had lost to South Africa in both formats but I must say I had relished the challenge of playing
against some of the best fast bowlers in the world.

Every side faces difficulties away from home and
at the end of the tough South Africa series we were looking forward to dishing out a few challenges to
Graham Gooch’s England when they toured India in February–March 1993.

We really needed that win after the
disappointment in South Africa and it felt particularly great to see the spinners come into play in
conditions that suited their art.
It’s fair to say that we had successfully put the disappointment of South Africa behind us.

In ODIs we had started winning close contests and we went into the next
major one-day tournament – the Hero Cup, also featuring South Africa, Sri Lanka, the West Indies and
Zimbabwe – as one of the favourites.

The one match of the Hero Cup I will never forget is the semi-final against South Africa on 24
November 1993.

We knew we needed to
bowl and field exceedingly well if we were to stop South Africa from making the final.

Our bowlers,
led by Anil, did a very good job and at the end of the forty-ninth over South Africa needed six runs to
win.

But in the process South Africa lost Fanie de Villiers, who,
in trying to get McMillan back on strike, was run out by a throw from Salil Ankola.
Yadav easily picked up the ball twenty yards back and South Africa could only sneak a single.

Next on the horizon was a home Test series against South Africa, which was preceded by another

It was no small
achievement to beat Australia and South Africa, two of the best teams in the world at the time, on our
way to the title.

After we were bowled out for a modest 223 in the first innings, South Africa
managed a handy 21-run lead.

We faltered
and left South Africa needing just 170 to win in a little under two days.
At no time during the chase were South Africa in with a chance.

Though we reverted to Sourav at three and Rahul at five for the deciding third
Test of this series and the first two Tests in South Africa shortly afterwards, we repeated the
experiment in the third and final Test of that series at Johannesburg in January 1997.

In the second Test of the home series at Eden Gardens at the end of November 1996, South Africa
beat us comfortably, with Lance Klusener and Gary Kirsten playing well for the visitors.

Azhar was in commanding form in the
second innings, remaining undefeated on 163, and once we had managed to set South Africa a target of
over 450 we knew we were in control.

We bowled South Africa out for 180, winning the Test by 280
runs and the series 2–1.

To beat Australia and South Africa in my first two series as captain was the
best start I could have hoped for, and when we left for South Africa in December 1996 we were a team
brimming with confidence.

To beat Australia and South Africa in my first two series as captain was the
best start I could have hoped for, and when we left for South Africa in December 1996 we were a team
brimming with confidence.

India in South Africa, December 1996–February 1997
The planning for the return series was not the best.

We landed in South Africa on 19 December and
played just one practice game before the first Test match in Durban on Boxing Day.

Balls that hit the bottom half of the bat in India come
at heights close to the bat handle in South Africa.

Sourav too batted extremely well at number five and we scored 410
in our first innings, which put South Africa under pressure for the first time in the series.

It was a torrential downpour and it soon became clear
that we had lost a great opportunity to win a Test match in South Africa.

The Test series

India in South Africa, December 2010–January 2011
Playing South Africa in South Africa was always a difficult proposition.

India in South Africa, December 2010–January 2011
Playing South Africa in South Africa was always a difficult proposition.

We had lost eight wickets by the end of day four and on the final day South Africa closed out the
match comfortably to win by ten wickets.

They combined well to finish South Africa off for just 131 in their first innings and were aided by
some brilliant catching behind the wickets.

In the third and deciding Test match at Cape Town on 2 January 2011, South Africa batted first on a
pitch that offered reasonable help for the seam bowlers throughout the match.

Kallis played brilliantly again, however, and, thanks to his 161, South Africa
posted a competitive 362 in their first innings.

When Harbhajan Singh came in, we were still more than a hundred runs behind South Africa and
needed one more decent partnership to get close to their total, but Harbhajan was finding it difficult to
negotiate Steyn’s fast swinging deliveries.
Looking back, this was our best chance to win a series in South Africa.

With half the side out for 98,
all we needed was one final burst to roll over the opposition, but instead we let South Africa off the

 hook.

In normal circumstances, a 1–1 series result in South Africa would be considered a really
good performance, but this was clearly a contest we should have won.

ANJALI

As I was trying to establish myself as an international cricketer, my personal life changed
dramatically in August 1990 when I met Anjali, my future wife.

At the time she was in England
with her parents, and her father, Anand Mehta, a former national bridge champion and a serious
cricket fan, had called her to catch a glimpse of the innings on television.

 unconscious, while Arjun was seriously sick at home.

When a friend of his accosted him at
school and said that India had lost because his dad had got out for zero, our advice went out of his
head and Arjun punched the boy and told him not to say anything bad about his father again.

WINDING DOWN

After surgery on my left hand in London in July 2013, I worked hard on getting back to full fitness.

6:
When I said I had to leave for Newcastle because I was playing there the next day I could
see the shock and bewilderment on their faces.

I was
advised to leave for Newcastle straight away.

I had left Yorkshire at one o’clock that
afternoon to get down to London, and here I was at midnight getting ready to drive all the way to
Newcastle.

There were roadworks
everywhere as we got out of Newcastle and the speed limit had been brought down to 55 mph from the
normal 70 mph.

Every other time Solly bhai’s family
kindly came to my rescue.

Farewell Eden Gardens
Having relaxed for a couple of days at home in Mumbai, and having visited the temples in Mumbai
and Goa that I always visit to seek the blessings of God, I arrived in Kolkata on the evening of 3
November 2013.

Kolkata
has always been a city that loves its cricket and the people there have always embraced me with
warmth.

During my first two days in Kolkata, Pintu (Raghunath Basak) gave me a massage for almost two
hours each day to help me relax and my friend Samar Paul brought me food from home and we all had
dinner in my room with Virat, Rohit, Ajinkya and Pragyan Ojha.

Every visit to Kolkata has been made special by
the food that Samarda has kindly brought from home.

Pintu too has been a constant in Kolkata from
1994, and it has been a routine that he would give me a massage and we would then end up having
dinner in my room.

Also, Joydeep Mukherjee would always take me to the Kali temple whenever I
went to Kolkata, visits I have always looked forward to.
This is what Anjali told me about making that special trip to Kolkata.

STANDING UP FOR MYSELF

In July 2001, two months after the Australia series, we played a tri-series against the West Indies and

Food on tour was always an important consideration for the team and to get the kind of food we
liked in places such as Bulawayo in Zimbabwe and some South African cities could sometimes be a
real problem.

Jhanak bhai, the man in question, was a Gujarati settled in Zimbabwe and he ended up inviting the
team to his home, where we feasted on a home-cooked meal of Gujarati-style dal, rice and ghee.

Others who have been kind enough to provide us
with good home-cooked food in Zimbabwe and South Africa are Raj and Chester Naik and Jayesh
Desai.

innings.

celebrating in Mohali.

dedicated to my father – my mind was not always on the game.

Our next three matches were against Kenya, Sri Lanka and New Zealand and we won them all

beating a few of the top-ranked teams.

In fact, during the match between Kenya and Sri Lanka, which
we watched in the games room in our hotel, a rather odd thing happened.

It was strange and in no time Kenya had
caused a huge upset.

Standing up for justice
We were preparing to travel to Canberra the day after the Sydney Test to play a first-class fixture
when we heard that Bhajji had been banned for three matches.

Anil Kumble and I took the lead and it was unanimously decided that we would boycott the tour if
Bhajji’s ban was upheld.

If Bhajji’s ban was upheld, it would mean an acceptance of guilt and imply that Bhajji had
racially abused Symonds, which he most certainly had not.

by Bhajji with six wickets, delivered once again to set up a very satisfying win.
22:
Bhajji, who has a phenomenal
record in Kolkata, bowled superbly, finishing with eight wickets in the match, and we took the final
South African wicket with just a few overs remaining.

The Eden Gardens crowd was behind us and the
last wicket, Morne Morkel lbw to Bhajji, was greeted with a deafening roar.

Bhajji ran almost half the
length of the ground in delight and we were thrilled to have pulled off a stunning victory.

Zaheer came back to lead our
attack and both he and Bhajji bowled brilliantly after we had made a modest 205 in our first innings.

Rahul picked up his 200th catch in this match when he
caught Dale Steyn off Bhajji at slip.
It was now up to Zaheer, Ishant, Sreesanth and Bhajji to finish the job and level the series.
I remember Bhajji running beside the ball and urging Smith to go for a second run.

Bhajji had scored consecutive hundreds against New
Zealand in the series before and was in good batting form, but those conditions were not best suited to
him.

Bhajji has power and the
shot sailed over the long-on boundary at least ten rows back for a huge six.

To add insult to injury,
Bhajji offered a wry smile to Steyn, who by now was furious.

Bhajji’s assault forced Graeme Smith to push his fielders back and so I walked up to Bhajji again to
say that he could stop trying to hit every ball now; he could just tap the ball and run.

Bhajji’s assault forced Graeme Smith to push his fielders back and so I walked up to Bhajji again to
say that he could stop trying to hit every ball now; he could just tap the ball and run.

Our partnership
yielded 76 very valuable runs and when Bhajji was finally out for 40 with the score on 323 we were
within striking distance of the South African total.
Our bowlers started well in the South African second innings and Bhajji was again simply brilliant.

Bhajji took seven wickets, but unfortunately the fast bowlers weren’t quite so successful at the
other end.
23:
In one
memorable moment Virat, Bhajji and Yuvi went down on their knees and sang ‘ Tujme rabh dikhta hai
yaara mai kya karu’ (What to do, my friend, in you we see God himself!)
24:
To add to our concerns, we lost Yuvraj in the second Test when he fractured his finger, then Bhajji
suffered a stomach-muscle tear and Gautam Gambhir fell over and had severe concussion, which

 prevented him from opening the batting in the fourth Test.
25:
I realized that I needed to take my mind off cricket for a while, so I called Yuvi, Zaheer and Bhajji
and suggested that we should watch a movie in the hotel room on reaching Kolkata for the third Test.

Forty-five minutes into the film Bhajji said, ‘Paaji yeh log kuch bolenge ki
film aise hi chalta rahega?’ (Brother, are they going to say anything or is it going to continue in this
silent vein for the whole movie?)

9:
Bhaji, who always enjoyed a laugh, was aware of what Harvinder had
done and kept asking him if he was enjoying his food!
Thinking of this match reminds me of a story about Anshuman Gaekwad.

Ravi Shastri, Shane Warne and
Richie Benaud, former Australian captain and one of the greatest cricketers to have played the game,
were also present and I had a brief non-cricketing chat with them all before returning to the hotel.

What I remember about that competition is that the Zimbabwe fast bowler Henry Olonga had taken
me by surprise in the last match of the group stage with a short ball and the manner of my dismissal
had kept me restless right up to the final.

The ball was finally pulled up yards from the rope by the substitute fielder Nadeem Khan.

In hindsight, I should not have played the Delhi and Kolkata Test matches that followed, but my
urge to play against Pakistan drove me on.

Anil has won
many Test matches for India and he was unplayable at the Kotla in Delhi, as he became only the
second bowler in the history of Test cricket, after Jim Laker in 1956, to pick up all ten wickets in an
innings.

In Pakistan’s second innings I handed Anil’s sweater and cap to umpire Arani Jayaprakash
before every over he bowled.
Despite the direct hit, I would have been well in if I hadn’t collided with Shoaib Akhtar.

fast bowler Shoaib Akhtar would swing his bowling arm twice before he delivered his effort ball as he

India v Sri Lanka at Taunton.

My foot started to trouble me on the first day of the

10:
An unexpected appointment
The back pain continued to bother me after the World Cup and in fact turned worse in the twin
tournaments in Sri Lanka and Singapore in August–September 1999, at the end of which I decided to
go to Australia to get my back examined.

I had already resorted to acupuncture and acupressure – and
even had my tongue pricked by an expert in Singapore trying to identify the pressure points that might
help in the recovery.
18:
On our way to Australia, Harbhajan Singh and I had bought a newly launched moisturizing
cream at Singapore airport and for the first few days I had no problems using the cream.

10:
Winning this battle against

 Chris Cairns definitely helped us save the match.

In this Test match we were at the receiving end of what seemed to us to be a howler from umpire
Daryl Harper.

The team score
was at 215–4 and another hundred runs could have helped set up the match, but just as we were
looking to consolidate, Daryl Harper gave me out bat-pad to Shane Warne, caught by Justin Langer at
forward short leg.

Michael Slater, Justin Langer, the Waugh twins, Ricky Ponting and Adam Gilchrist all in good form.

I played a full-blooded pull shot to a short Mark Waugh delivery, which would
have been a definite boundary had the ball not hit Justin Langer’s back at forward short leg and
spooned up to midwicket.

10:
McGrath and Brett Lee, who made his debut in the series,

15:
I faced only one ball,
getting a faint tickle down the leg side to Gilchrist, who was standing way back to Brett Lee.
18:
Bhajji was doing his best and was actually trying to be civil with some of the Australian players,
including Brett Lee, when all hell broke loose.

Sehwag was back and he gave us a
quick start against Brett Lee, Mitchell Johnson, Shaun Tait and Stuart Clark on the first morning,
helping us to win the first skirmish.
It was in this innings that I had one of my toughest contests with Brett Lee.

I’m pleased to say that Brett Lee and Adam Gilchrist also
came to our dressing room to congratulate us and it was a gesture that was much appreciated.

When he asked me at Adelaide if I wanted to practise against short throw-downs, I asked him to
throw full and fast at me, because I had a feeling Brett Lee would bowl a full-length delivery the

 moment I went in, as he had got me out with a full delivery at Perth.
19:
The only scare was a beamer from Brett Lee that hit me on the side of my helmet grille and the

10: I had discussed my decision with my family in Lonavla, where we had gone for a break.

Dhoni had already captained the team with distinction in the Twenty20 format and had also done
well in the fifty-over format.
Dhoni, in contrast, was impulsive and loved to back his instincts.
15: Dhoni was our captain then and Gary Kirsten our coach.
17:
Although Sourav scored 66 while opening the batting, Rahul,
the captain, made only 14 and then Dhoni got out for a duck trying to play a cut shot, caught at short
third man.
18:
Andrew Symonds was ruled not out after he had very clearly edged the ball to
Dhoni off Ishant – the sound was heard not just by the players but also by the spectators.

Finally, umpire Bucknor gave
Dhoni out leg-before when to us the ball would clearly have missed the stumps.
19:
We fielded first and
Dhoni was standing way back and still had to catch most balls at chest height.

I
remember mentioning to Dhoni, after an outside edge off Matthew Hayden’s bat flew past me, that the
pitch was going to favour the fast bowlers throughout the match and no chase was going to be easy.

When I got out in the twenty-sixth over we needed 64 runs and Rohit
Sharma and Dhoni played well to finish off the job.

Dhoni came out next and we knocked off the 30 runs needed to finish the match quite easily in the
end.

Seeing my
condition, Dhoni suggested that maybe I should miss the second final and play in the third if needed.

It was bound to
be difficult for batting early on and the obvious plan was to field first if we won the toss – but I urged
Dhoni not to do so.
Dhoni agreed and we batted first.

In fact, I
was forced to leave the field in the fourth over of the Australia innings, when Dhoni dived to catch
Hayden off Sreesanth and the ball ricocheted and hit me exactly where I had been hit by the Lee
beamer.

In contrast, the Australian bowlers had
found it difficult to get their rhythm right and Gambhir, Sehwag and Dhoni had all made big scores
against them.

I suggested to Dhoni that we needed to slow down the
game, and after that we employed an 8–1 field, with eight fielders on the off side and one on the on,
something hardly ever tried in Test cricket, to Michael Hussey and Simon Katich, and despite
dropping Katich early on we managed to restrict the runs.
21:
In the five-match one-day series, we easily won the rain-affected first match, thanks largely to the
batting of Sehwag and Dhoni.

The match was a high-scoring one and, despite setting a target of 392, with Yuvraj Singh and Dhoni
both making half-centuries, we were not safe.

I asked Dhoni to take the fielder away from point and place two fielders at
short square leg.

I was having breakfast with MS Dhoni and had my back to the restaurant door when I saw in
Dhoni’s eyes that something was going on behind me.

Centuries from Dravid and Dhoni
had helped us to a decent first-innings total of 426, but Sri Lanka had scored 760 runs in response,
thanks to hundreds from Dilshan and Prasanna Jayawardene and a double hundred from Mahela
Jayawardene.
All Dhoni had to do was knock off the bails.
22:
We sensed we were in with a chance and put
together a big first-innings total, with as many as four of us – Sehwag, Laxman, Dhoni and myself –
getting hundreds.

Laxman and Dhoni built on the platform and we finally declared at a whopping 643–6, leaving the
South Africans two whole days to bat to save the game.

I was still running even when I was in the 190s,
while Dhoni was pounding the bowling at the other end.

Dhoni and I were involved in a very good
counter-attacking partnership of 172 and I was relieved to make my fiftieth Test hundred at last.

I mentioned
this to my batting partner Dhoni, saying ‘Yeh ball mere life mein pehle bhi aaya hai.
23:
Someone had pointed out that every time Dhoni had been involved in a
tie in a multi-nation competition, he had ended up winning the title.

This had been the case in the
World Twenty20 in 2007 (the India–Pakistan game was tied before India won in a bowl-out), in the
IPL and even in the 2010 Champions League Twenty20 that Dhoni had won.

We then lost Gautam and Dhoni in quick succession and
Suresh Raina, playing only his second World Cup game, joined Yuvraj in the middle with 74 runs still
needed.

Once Virat was out, Dhoni promoted himself up the order to
negotiate the Sri Lankan off-spinners, Muralitharan, Randiv and Dilshan.
Neither of us ventured out till Dhoni’s shot had crossed the boundary.

It was only after Dhoni’s shot had finally crossed the boundary
that I went out.
24:
MS Dhoni had
played a straight drive off Graeme Swann and the ball hit Swann’s hand and ricocheted onto the
stumps at the non-striker’s end, running me out.

Rahul was out in the first over the next morning and Laxman and
Dhoni followed soon after, handing Australia control of the match.

One of the main reasons I
played in the series was that MS Dhoni came and said to me, ‘Aap rukh jao.
25:
Virat
Kohli made a hundred and Dhoni was run out on 99, but my poor series continued as I was bowled by
James Anderson for two in my only innings.

Australia were keeping things tight and we finally reached a stage when Dhoni

 and I were at the crease and we needed 24 off twenty-five balls to win.

It was disappointing not to stay till the end and close out
the game myself, but Dhoni and Ravindra Jadeja did the job.
27:
But they were quickly disappointed when MS Dhoni opted to field because the wicket
was expected to offer some assistance to the fast bowlers in the morning.

When the ninth wicket fell and I ran in to congratulate the bowler, Dhoni asked me to stay away

10:
He was an excellent
strategist and even if some of his tactics occasionally bordered on the negative – using the left-arm
spinner Ashley Giles to bowl to me outside my leg stump from over the wicket, for example – he was
a very good thinker about the game and was proactive.
13:
It was in this series that Nasser instructed his left-arm spinner
Ashley Giles to bowl from over the wicket and consistently pitch the ball way outside my leg stump.

From memory, the conversation went
something like this:
NASSER: You have to agree that I was successful in stopping you and getting you frustrated during
the 2001 England tour of India when I got Ashley Giles to bowl to you from over the wicket.

He was bowling into Sourav’s body and it
was decided that I would face up to him while Sourav, a left-hander, took as much strike as possible
against Ashley Giles, who was once again bowling a defensive line to me outside my leg stump.
I was out bowled trying to cut a ball from Ashley Giles.

10: Among the Australians, I rate Michael Clarke as the best captain I played against.

our former players commenting on Ricky Ponting or Michael Clarke have had a headline in the

18:

Batting in much-improved conditions on days two and three, Australia
went on to run up a very big score, with skipper Michael Clarke contributing a triple hundred to their
659, and this left us two whole days to bat to save the match.

Once again I was
batting well and should have gone on, but infuriatingly I got myself out to part-time left-arm spinner
Michael Clarke for 80 to a ball which pitched around off stump on a fourth-day pitch with a few

 cracks and, just as I was trying to play forward, kissed the outside edge of my bat and hit Brad Haddin
on his thigh before going to Mike Hussey at slip.

Australia did well to make 380 in the first innings, with skipper Michael

11:
In Glenn McGrath,
Jason Gillespie, Damien Fleming, Michael Kasprowicz and Shane Warne they had a bowling line-up
capable of taking wickets in all conditions.

I had forged an important partnership with
Rahul, which was all the more satisfying because we had to negotiate a very hostile Jason Gillespie
spell with the second new ball.
15:
I lasted just three balls and was given out lbw to Jason Gillespie when the ball struck
the top flap of my pad.

11:
The batting was also exceptional, with Matthew Hayden,
Michael Slater, Justin Langer, the Waugh twins, Ricky Ponting and Adam Gilchrist all in good form.

Australia scored 445 in the first innings, thanks to 110 from Steve Waugh and 97 from Matthew
Hayden, and when we were at a dismal 128–8 at the end of day two, with the Australian quartet of
McGrath, Gillespie, Kasprowicz and Warne all taking wickets, not even the most ardent Indian fan
thought we’d be able to save the match.

It was one
of those rare days when the ball came out perfectly and I managed to take three quick wickets for the
team in a five-over spell, including the wickets of in-form Matthew Hayden and the dangerous Adam
Gilchrist.

Third Test, Chennai, 18–22 March 2001
The Australians started well, with Matthew Hayden once again leading the way.
19:
I
remember mentioning to Dhoni, after an outside edge off Matthew Hayden’s bat flew past me, that the
pitch was going to favour the fast bowlers throughout the match and no chase was going to be easy.

Australia
made 239 on the day, with Matthew Hayden contributing 82, and we didn’t think it was a bad total in
good bowling conditions.

11:
The batting was also exceptional, with Matthew Hayden,
Michael Slater, Justin Langer, the Waugh twins, Ricky Ponting and Adam Gilchrist all in good form.
The town of Bhuj in Gujarat was almost destroyed and we in Mumbai did not escape unscathed.

During the ODI series that followed, which we lost 2–3, I reached 10,000 runs in ODIs, in the third
game in Indore, and in the last match in Goa I did something that I have never done again in my life.

12:
STANDING UP FOR MYSELF

In July 2001, two months after the Australia series, we played a tri-series against the West Indies and
Zimbabwe at Harare.
14:
In our pool game against them in Harare we played
well from the start and won by 83 runs in the end.
Zimbabwe v India at Harare.

12:
After the match I showed the toe to Andrew Leipus, who had taken over as our physiotherapist, and
the next morning we went for an X-ray.
14:
On the first morning,
when the rest of the team were on the ground preparing to play, I was in hospital with Andrew Leipus
getting my finger checked.

12:
On the very same day Dr Dholakia started looking into where I
could go to get my toe examined by a specialist.

Eventually I found myself at the Rosebank Clinic in Johannesburg, where Dr Mark Ferguson, who
had worked with a lot of sportsmen, advised me to try out a few insoles.

I had, however, started to feel more confident after a net session at
Bloemfontein, the venue for the first of the three Tests.

The pitch in Bloemfontein
had a lot of bounce and in the absence of a third-man fielder the upper cut was a scoring stroke played
with minimal risk.
Bloemfontein.

I had come up with the idea of
the shot to counter the South African fast bowler Makhaya Ntini, whose strength was to bring the ball
in to the batsman from short of a length.
19:
Fielding in the heat quickly brought back the pain and when I
finally batted on the fourth day I was so stiff and sore that I got out without scoring to Makhaya Ntini,
caught by Kallis at second slip.

12:
Food on tour was always an important consideration for the team and to get the kind of food we
liked in places such as Bulawayo in Zimbabwe and some South African cities could sometimes be a
real problem.
I remember one occasion in Bulawayo when all the players were yearning for home food.

Jhanak bhai, the man in question, was a Gujarati settled in Zimbabwe and he ended up inviting the
team to his home, where we feasted on a home-cooked meal of Gujarati-style dal, rice and ghee.

It soon became a regular thing
and Jhanak bhai and his family fed us many times.

Others who have been kind enough to provide us
with good home-cooked food in Zimbabwe and South Africa are Raj and Chester Naik and Jayesh
Desai.

Raj and Chester Naik also took us to play golf and we had
some wonderful dinners together.

Rahul Dravid and Deep Dasgupta, our wicketkeeper, played resolutely on the last day, and we
saved the match comfortably in the end.

Deep Dasgupta, Harbhajan Singh and Shiv Sunder Das, the opening
batsman, were all handed a one-Test suspended ban and fined 75 per cent of their match fee for the
same offence.

However, what hit the headlines from that match were the
allegations made against me by the match referee Mike Denness, who also charged five other Indian
players.

I asked Mike Denness to consult the on-field umpires, because they had
checked the ball every two or three overs and were in the best position to tell if the ball had been
tampered with.

I informed Mike Denness that I would complain about the allegation to the BCCI and would not
keep quiet about it.

Apart from charging me with ball tampering, Mike Denness handed captain Sourav Ganguly a onematch suspended ban for failing to control the players and banned Virender Sehwag for one match on
a charge of over-appealing.

The
situation came to a head twenty-four hours before the start of the third Test match, when it was finally
decided by the Indian and South African boards, rather than by the ICC, that Mike Denness should not
officiate in the match.

Apart from charging me with ball tampering, Mike Denness handed captain Sourav Ganguly a onematch suspended ban for failing to control the players and banned Virender Sehwag for one match on
a charge of over-appealing.
15:
We batted first after winning the toss on 26 December and Virender Sehwag played what must be
one of the best Test innings ever seen at the MCG.

First Test, Multan, 28 March–1 April 2004
At Multan, Virender Sehwag played a blinder.
21:
I’m also reminded of what the Sri Lankans did against Virender Sehwag on 16 August 2010 during
a one-day international in Dambulla.

Our first three batsmen, Gautam Gambhir, Virender Sehwag and
Rahul Dravid, all got hundreds and the bowlers backed them up with some disciplined bowling, so that
we won by an innings and 144 runs.
At the CCI, Virender Sehwag produced one of the best Test innings I have seen.
23: We won the toss and Virender Sehwag and I stepped out to start our campaign.

The reason was that when Mahendra Singh
Dhoni hit the winning six at the Wankhede Stadium, I was with Virender Sehwag in the dressing room
praying.

13:
SACHIN: You did indeed, but despite his efforts, my batting average for the series was 76, with
scores of 88, 103 and 90 in the three Test matches, and I was in fact nominated Player of the Series.

The first of the four Tests, at Lord’s, started on 25 July 2002 and England won pretty
convincingly, with Hussain making his highest score for five years and Michael Vaughan also
contributing a century.

Sourav was out for 99 while I was
bowled for 92 by part-time off-spinner Michael Vaughan to what was probably the best ball he ever
bowled.
18:
The first Test started on 19
July 2007 and I have to say we were fortunate to avoid defeat after Michael Vaughan’s England had
put themselves in a good position.

13:
That we managed to hold on for a draw, thanks to some

 dour resistance from wicketkeeper Parthiv Patel, a teenager at the time, was an important statement
and it laid the foundation for the fightback at Headingley in the third Test.
14:
The pitch offered a lot of assistance to the fast bowlers and even Parthiv Patel, our wicketkeeper, was
getting the ball to swing prodigiously in the nets.
15:
Then, just as Parthiv Patel, the next batsman, started to come
out, I saw Rahul gesturing us to go back to the pavilion.

13:
That we managed to hold on for a draw, thanks to some

 dour resistance from wicketkeeper Parthiv Patel, a teenager at the time, was an important statement
and it laid the foundation for the fightback at Headingley in the third Test.

Third Test, Headingley, 22–26 August 2002
The wicket was very damp at the start of the Headingley Test on 22 August 2002.

At Trent Bridge in the previous Test we had played well to draw the match and now we had cashed
in at Headingley.

A special announcement was made and when it was my turn to bat people were expecting me
to carry on from where I had left off at Headingley.

NatWest Series, June–July 2002
The Headingley win, which helped us to draw the Test series, followed a memorable victory in the
NatWest tri-series, making it a fabulous English summer for India.

It was around then that a friend of mine suggested visiting the famous Harry Ramsden’s, in
Guiseley in West Yorkshire.

I had never
used one before, even in practice, but Andrew Flintoff was getting the ball to jag back in to the
batsmen and I thought the inner-thigh guard might be a sensible protection against injury.

When Andrew Flintoff got out for a pair, caught by Dravid at slip off Zaheer
Khan, our left-arm fast bowler, we knew we were within striking distance of a famous victory.
14:
It was a dream start in a very big game and it took a great spell from Andrew Flintoff to bring
England back into the match.

13:
The following
morning Matthew Hoggard, who had the ability to swing the ball both ways, also bowled impressively,
getting the ball to move away from the bat at good pace.

In fact, it was a low bounce that cost me my wicket
on the morning of the third day, when I was lbw to Andrew Caddick for 193.
14:
Apparently Andrew Caddick said a number of things before the game and our players who read
those statements were fired up on the eve of the match.

13:
When Andrew Flintoff got out for a pair, caught by Dravid at slip off Zaheer
Khan, our left-arm fast bowler, we knew we were within striking distance of a famous victory.

In Zaheer Khan, Ashish Nehra, Javagal
Srinath, Anil Kumble and Harbhajan Singh we had a more than competent bowling line-up, and with
Sehwag, Sourav, Rahul, Yuvraj, Kaif and myself, we were capable of out-batting any opposition.
18:
We dismissed England for under 200, thanks to
excellent bowling from Zaheer Khan and Anil Kumble, with good support from RP Singh and
Sreesanth, and followed up with a total of 481.
Our innings was tinged with controversy when Zaheer Khan had an unusual welcome to the middle.
19:
The ball was reverse-swinging and both Zaheer Khan
and Ishant Sharma were making the most of the conditions.
20:
The
youngsters in the team mixed with the senior players and I remember that Zaheer Khan, Harbhajan
and I were asked a series of questions by the other players about our careers and our lives as Indian
cricketers.
21:
My knock of 160 contributed to a
sizeable first-innings lead, alongside fifties from Gambhir, Dravid and Zaheer Khan.

In the third Test in Wellington, we scored a reasonable 379, batting first, but then Zaheer Khan and
Harbhajan Singh combined to bowl out New Zealand for 197, giving us a 182-run lead.
23:
We simply had to get the campaign back on track in the next match,
against the West Indies in Chennai on 20 March, and we managed to do just that, thanks to a Yuvraj
Singh century and a surprise slower ball from Zaheer Khan to dismiss the in-form Devon Smith for
81.
I heard Zaheer Khan and Ashish Nehra banging on my door, wanting to share a drink.
25:
In the leadup to the season I continued to be bothered by the toe injury, so much so that I visited BKS Iyengar,
one of the foremost yoga gurus in the world, together with Zaheer Khan for a day in May 2012, during
the fifth edition of the IPL.

13:
I was nervous and excited on the morning of the game and the
chief executive of Surrey County Cricket Club, Paul Sheldon, presented me with a commemorative
plaque.

For example, every time Ben
Hilfenhaus, the Australian fast bowler, held an old ball cross-seam, I knew he would bowl a bouncer –
and I would be prepared for it.
24: I was playing aggressively and followed up the Siddle cover drive with another off Ben Hilfenhaus.

It had got a little cloudy in the evening and with Ben Hilfenhaus and Peter Siddle
bowling really well, I was satisfied to survive the last hour so that I could resume the following
morning.

13:
In the case of the Sri Lankan legend Muttiah Muralitharan, he would have his thumb on
top of the ball when bowling a doosra.

The commentators, including Harsha Bhogle on
air, said they were impressed because they had not been able to pick the doosra and the replay had not
yet been shown.
26:
I knew I had to be careful, because
on a previous occasion I had had to make a similar speech and thought I had thanked everybody – until
the commentator Harsha Bhogle came to the rescue and whispered in my ear that I hadn’t mentioned
Anjali!

13:
I had first seen Collins in a practice match during our May–June 2002 tour of the West Indies,
when he bowled our opening batsman Wasim Jaffer with a big inswinger.

So by the
time of the final Test in Jamaica I was more confident against him and I managed to score 86.
17:
We played well in our two practice matches against the Netherlands and the West Indies in Jamaica
in early March.

13:
By
now the mood in the dressing room had turned sombre and nobody was speaking – until Yuvraj Singh,
the talented left-handed batsman, and Mohammad Kaif, a right-handed middle-order batsman and
excellent fielder, started an unlikely recovery act.
14:
Our bowlers then dismissed the opposition for 130, with Yuvraj
Singh taking four wickets for six runs, and though not much could be read into our performance
against a team like Namibia, it was apparent that things were moving in the right direction.
21:
The match was a high-scoring one and, despite setting a target of 392, with Yuvraj Singh and Dhoni
both making half-centuries, we were not safe.
23: In Dhaka I invited Yuvraj Singh to my room to have dinner.

We simply had to get the campaign back on track in the next match,
against the West Indies in Chennai on 20 March, and we managed to do just that, thanks to a Yuvraj
Singh century and a surprise slower ball from Zaheer Khan to dismiss the in-form Devon Smith for
81.

14: The New Zealand experience was best summed up by the home captain Stephen Fleming.

As a result, at our training camp in Paarl, in the Western Cape, I was not able to
run with the team and spent my time cycling to keep up my cardio exercises.
India v Netherlands at Paarl.

It was frustrating, but I
knew I had to push myself to get back to fitness before the first match of the tournament against the
Netherlands on 12 February.

The pool games

 The less-than-impressive performances in our warm-up matches had made the first pool match on 12
February 2003, against the Netherlands, extremely important.

Even if the Netherlands were not the best opposition in the world,
they had some good players in their team who had experience of playing on the county circuit in
England.

It wasn’t a score to rave about and we knew that with one good innings from a Netherlands
batsman we might have a contest on our hands.
India v Netherlands at Paarl.
17:
We played well in our two practice matches against the Netherlands and the West Indies in Jamaica
in early March.

We scored 300 batting first against the Netherlands, for a decisive 182-run win, and in
the next match our bowlers polished off the West Indies for 85, setting up a nine-wicket victory.
23:
There’s many a slip
We won our next two pool matches against Ireland and the Netherlands fairly comfortably and met

 South Africa in Nagpur on 12 March 2011.

India v Namibia at Pietermaritzburg.

While we batted reasonably in
the first game on 4 February in Pietermaritzburg, with Yuvi and Dravid both doing well, the game on

15:
Yuvi was run out for 86
and then Gautam was out for 97, which was when we finally declared the innings at 251–7.

Though Yuvi scored a very good hundred for us, we were always playing catch-up and
were never in the contest.
18:
We forced Yuvi to admit that he had never tried wasabi before and we ribbed him mercilessly,
though he tried to put on a brave face.
21:
To celebrate taking a 3–0 lead in the series, Bhajji, Zaheer, Yuvi and I met up in
Bhajji’s room for dinner, which was next to the health club in the hotel.
23:
I have always enjoyed a special
friendship with Yuvi and believed that he had a key role to play in the tournament.

Yuvi was a little
down at the time, as things had not been going well for him, so I encouraged him to set some targets
and concentrate on meeting them.

I was finally out for 120 and, with fifties from
Gambhir and Yuvi, we made 338 in our fifty overs.

And when Yuvi hit the final boundary, the
Indian dressing room went mad.

Riaz bowled Yuvi first ball and the momentum shifted like a pendulum
many times in the course of the match.

In one
memorable moment Virat, Bhajji and Yuvi went down on their knees and sang ‘ Tujme rabh dikhta hai
yaara mai kya karu’ (What to do, my friend, in you we see God himself!)
25:
I realized that I needed to take my mind off cricket for a while, so I called Yuvi, Zaheer and Bhajji
and suggested that we should watch a movie in the hotel room on reaching Kolkata for the third Test.
27:
All of Arjun’s friends were delighted to see Yuvi and Arjun was proud to be dropped off
by him.

14:
I scored 81 off ninety-one
balls and Bhajji picked up the crucial wicket of Andy Flower, Zimbabwe’s best batsman.

not to take it easy against a relatively weak team.

Our bowlers then dismissed the opposition for 130, with Yuvraj
Singh taking four wickets for six runs, and though not much could be read into our performance
against a team like Namibia, it was apparent that things were moving in the right direction.
India v Namibia at Pietermaritzburg.

We picked up Marcus Trescothick, the other opener, when he mistimed a pull off Zaheer and ended
up giving me an easy catch at backward square.

Saeed Anwar held the
innings together and made a very important hundred for his team.

Dr Anant Joshi, as

I lasted just six balls before I was caught by Gilchrist
off the fast bowler Andy Bichel.

We fielded brilliantly in this innings
and took some amazing catches, Aakash Chopra’s catch of Ponting at point off Ajit being the standout.

had given us and we were all out for 366, allowing Australia back into the game.

Steve Waugh and Damien Martyn had put
together a good partnership and it was immensely satisfying to be able to get both of them out caught
in the slips.

Multan.

16:
UNDER THE KNIFE

It started in Amsterdam, of all places.

It was an unfortunate situation because my in-laws had travelled to Amsterdam with their friends
from London to see me play and here I was nursing what was later diagnosed as tennis elbow.

An expert in Amsterdam tried to help it by
manipulating my wrist.

Helped by another five-wicket haul from Harbhajan and three from the left-arm
spinner Murali Kartik, who was the Player of the Match, we proceeded to bowl Australia out for just
93 and won the match by 13 runs.

I could barely sleep and would have to go out for long drives in
the middle of the night with my friend Faisal Momen just to try and calm down a little.
19:
After landing in Mumbai, my friend Faisal Momen picked me up and for the first time in my life I
asked him to drive as slowly as possible.
26:
When I’d got back from England my friends Atul Ranade, Faisal Momen and I
decided to start cycling as a part of my cardio exercise.

Unbeknown to me, Anirudh had invited a few of my closest
friends – Sameer Dighe, Faisal Momen and Jagdish Chavan – to watch the game.

16: I was in Baroda when I got to know that my surgeon, Dr Andrew Wallace, was in Delhi for a day.
19:
Finally, it was in London, when I was there for a family
holiday, that I met up with my surgeon Andrew Wallace and explained my condition.

16:
John Gloster, our new physio,
accompanied me to the hospital and the scans revealed a small cyst next to a nerve.

I was desperate to speak to John
Gloster and report what had happened, but John was then in the West Indies with the team and,
because of the time difference, I had to wait eight or nine hours before I was able to speak to him.
19:
Immediately after the match, I started to feel some soreness in my adductors, the muscles in the
groin, and informed John Gloster about the problem.

When I got up the following morning the pain was substantially reduced, but John Gloster and I
decided I should undertake a fitness test.

At the end of the match, which was a high-scoring draw, I told Anil
Kumble and John Gloster that there was no point in pushing my body any further.

16:
My first scoring shot was
a cover drive for four against the medium-pacer Farveez Maharoof and I flicked the next ball to
square leg for another boundary.

Vaas was bowling wide of my off stump
with a packed off-side field and I knew I had to try something different.

In the next over from Vaas, by which
time I had picked up two more singles, I had already made up my mind not to repeat the shot.

I
predicted that Vaas would be expecting me to paddle-sweep and would change his line and bowl to me
on the stumps.

My family and friends Atul Ranade and Jagdish Chavan were with me throughout the
recovery and I got them to bowl at me from 18 yards to get used to the extra pace that I was likely to
encounter in the West Indies.
19:
Throughout this period, my group of friends, including
Atul Ranade, Sameer Dighe and Jagdish Chavan, were always there to motivate me and would train
with me all day.

17:
I got an inside edge to a ball from fast bowler Dilhara Fernando; hearing the ball hitting the
stumps in such a crucial match was devastating.

My family and friends like Sanjay Nayak did
all they could to cheer me up and after a week I decided to do something about it.

On top of all this our coach, Greg Chappell, was publicly questioning our commitment and instead
of asking us to take fresh guard, was making matters worse.

It seems to me that Greg Chappell must
take a lot of responsibility for the mess.

It came to light later that Greg was being filmed for a documentary, Guru Greg, during this
period which went into a lot of detail about what was happening behind the scenes.

I have never quite understood why Ian Chappell,
who was merely reporting on the game, should have got a headline in the Indian press.

I remember meeting Ian Chappell in Durban in 2010 during the Champions League Twenty20 and
having a most interesting discussion with him.

I bumped into him as I was coming out of a health club
after a session in the gym with my physio, Nitin Patel, who was party to the entire exchange.

In fact, Nitin Patel told me soon after that I was the last person
he had expected to lash out like this.
